title: Place Value to 1000
description: Understand hundreds, tens and ones for numbers up to 1000
objectives: Read and write numbers up to 1000
Identify the value of each digit in a three-digit number
Represent numbers using hundreds, tens and ones

sections.title: Welcome to the World of Big Numbers!
sections.content:
You already know how to work with numbers up to 120. Now it's time to go even bigger -- all the way to **1000**!

The secret to understanding big numbers is **place value**. Every digit in a number has a special position that tells us how much it's worth. Let's explore how hundreds, tens and ones work together to make numbers up to 1000.

sections.title: Hundreds, Tens and Ones
sections.content:
A three-digit number has three places:

| Place | What it means | Example: 347 |
|-------|--------------|---------------|
| Hundreds | Groups of 100 | 3 hundreds = $300$ |
| Tens | Groups of 10 | 4 tens = $40$ |
| Ones | Single units | 7 ones = $7$ |

So $347 = 300 + 40 + 7$.

This is called **expanded form** -- breaking a number into the value of each digit.

Some important three-digit numbers:
- The smallest three-digit number is $100$
- The largest three-digit number is $999$
- After $999$ comes $1000$ (one thousand)

$$1000 = 10 \text{ hundreds} = 100 \text{ tens} = 1000 \text{ ones}$$

sections.title: Example: What Is This Number Worth?
sections.content: What is the value of each digit in **582**?
steps: The digit 5 is in the hundreds place: $5 \times 100 = 500$
The digit 8 is in the tens place: $8 \times 10 = 80$
The digit 2 is in the ones place: $2 \times 1 = 2$

sections.title: Example: Building a Number
sections.content: A number has 6 hundreds, 0 tens and 4 ones. What is the number?
steps: The number is **604**. Notice the 0 in the tens place -- it holds the position!

sections.title: Zero as a Placeholder
sections.content:
The digit **0** is very important in place value! It holds a position even when there are no groups of that value.

- $305$ has 3 hundreds, **0 tens** and 5 ones
- $350$ has 3 hundreds, 5 tens and **0 ones**
- $503$ has 5 hundreds, **0 tens** and 3 ones

These are all different numbers even though they use the same digits. **Position matters!**

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Awesome work! In this lesson you learned:

- Numbers up to 1000 have **hundreds**, **tens** and **ones**
- **Expanded form** shows the value of each digit: $347 = 300 + 40 + 7$
- **Zero** is a placeholder that holds a position
- The smallest three-digit number is $100$ and the largest is $999$

Try looking at house numbers or page numbers and working out the value of each digit!

workedExamples.title: Writing in Expanded Form
workedExamples.explanation: Each digit's value depends on its position. The 7 is in the hundreds place so it is worth $7 \times 100 = 700$, not just 7.

workedExamples.title: Which Digit Has the Greatest Value?
workedExamples.problem: In the number 463, which digit has the greatest value?
steps: The digit 4 is in the hundreds place: $4 \times 100 = 400$
The digit 6 is in the tens place: $6 \times 10 = 60$
The digit 3 is in the ones place: $3 \times 1 = 3$
workedExamples.solution: The digit **4** has the greatest value because it is worth $400$.
workedExamples.explanation: Even though 6 is a bigger digit than 4, the digit 4 is worth more because it is in the hundreds place. Position is more important than the digit itself!

title: Addition and Subtraction to 100
description: Add and subtract two-digit numbers using place value strategies
objectives: Add two-digit numbers using place value
Subtract two-digit numbers using place value
Solve addition and subtraction word problems

sections.title: Adding and Subtracting Bigger Numbers
sections.content:
Now that you understand place value, you can use it to add and subtract two-digit numbers. The big idea is to **break numbers into tens and ones** and work with each part separately.

This makes adding numbers like $34 + 25$ much easier than trying to count on 25 from 34!

sections.title: Adding with Place Value
sections.content:
To add two-digit numbers, add the **tens** first, then the **ones**.

**Example:** $34 + 25$

$$34 + 25 = (30 + 4) + (20 + 5)$$
$$= (30 + 20) + (4 + 5)$$
$$= 50 + 9 = 59$$

Sometimes the ones add up to more than 10. When that happens, we **regroup** (carry).

**Example:** $47 + 36$

$$47 + 36 = (40 + 7) + (30 + 6)$$
$$= (40 + 30) + (7 + 6)$$
$$= 70 + 13$$
$$= 70 + 10 + 3 = 83$$

The ones $7 + 6 = 13$, which is $1$ extra ten and $3$ ones.

sections.title: Subtracting with Place Value
sections.content:
Subtraction works the same way -- break numbers into tens and ones.

**Example:** $68 - 23$

$$68 - 23 = (60 + 8) - (20 + 3)$$
$$= (60 - 20) + (8 - 3)$$
$$= 40 + 5 = 45$$

If the ones digit being subtracted is bigger, you'll need to **regroup** (borrow).

**Example:** $52 - 27$

We can't do $2 - 7$, so we borrow a ten:
$$52 = 40 + 12$$
$$52 - 27 = (40 + 12) - (20 + 7)$$
$$= (40 - 20) + (12 - 7)$$
$$= 20 + 5 = 25$$

sections.title: Example: Addition Word Problem
sections.content: There are 38 students in Year 2A and 45 students in Year 2B. How many students are there altogether?

sections.title: Checking with Inverse Operations
sections.content:
Addition and subtraction are **opposites** (inverse operations). You can check your answer by doing the opposite operation.

If $38 + 45 = 83$, then:
- $83 - 45 = 38$ ✓
- $83 - 38 = 45$ ✓

If $52 - 27 = 25$, then:
- $25 + 27 = 52$ ✓

Always check your work!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Well done! In this lesson you learned:

- **Break numbers into tens and ones** to add or subtract
- When ones add up to more than 10, **regroup** the extra ten
- When you can't subtract the ones, **borrow** a ten
- Use **inverse operations** to check your answers

Practise adding and subtracting with numbers you see around you, like prices in a shop!

workedExamples.title: Addition with Regrouping
workedExamples.explanation: The ones digits add to 13, which is more than 10. We regroup the extra ten: $80 + 13 = 80 + 10 + 3 = 93$.

workedExamples.title: Subtraction with Regrouping
steps: We can't do $1 - 8$, so borrow a ten from 70
workedExamples.explanation: Since we can't take 8 from 1, we borrow a ten: $71$ becomes $60 + 11$. Then $60 - 40 = 20$ and $11 - 8 = 3$, giving us $23$. Check: $23 + 48 = 71$ ✓

title: Introduction to Multiplication
description: Understand multiplication as equal groups and repeated addition
objectives: Understand multiplication as making equal groups
Connect multiplication to skip counting and repeated addition
Use the multiplication symbol and read multiplication sentences

sections.title: Groups, Groups, Groups!
sections.content:
Imagine you have 4 bags, and each bag has 3 apples. How many apples altogether?

You could add: $3 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 12$. But there's a faster way -- **multiplication**!

$$4 \times 3 = 12$$

Multiplication means making **equal groups**. When every group has the same number, you can multiply instead of adding over and over.

sections.title: What Multiplication Means
sections.content:
The multiplication symbol is $\times$ and we read it as "times" or "groups of".

$$4 \times 3 = 12$$

This means **4 groups of 3** equals **12**.

| Groups | Items in each group | Repeated addition | Multiplication |
|--------|-------------------|--------------------|----------------|
| 2 groups of 5 | $5 + 5$ | $= 10$ | $2 \times 5 = 10$ |
| 3 groups of 4 | $4 + 4 + 4$ | $= 12$ | $3 \times 4 = 12$ |
| 5 groups of 2 | $2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2$ | $= 10$ | $5 \times 2 = 10$ |

**Multiplication is a shortcut for repeated addition!**

Notice that $2 \times 5$ and $5 \times 2$ both equal $10$. Just like addition, you can **swap the numbers** and the answer stays the same.

sections.title: Example: Equal Groups at School
sections.content: There are 3 tables in the classroom, and 6 children sit at each table. How many children altogether?
steps: Identify how many in each group: **6 children** per table

sections.title: Example: Arrays
sections.content:
An **array** is a way to show multiplication using rows and columns.

Imagine 4 rows of stars with 5 stars in each row:

$$\star \star \star \star \star$$
$$\star \star \star \star \star$$
$$\star \star \star \star \star$$
$$\star \star \star \star \star$$

- **4 rows** of **5** = $4 \times 5 = 20$ stars
- You can also see it as **5 columns** of **4** = $5 \times 4 = 20$ stars

Both ways give the same answer!
steps: Count the items in each row: 5 stars

sections.title: Multiplication and Skip Counting
sections.content:
Remember skip counting? It's the same as multiplication!

**Skip counting by 2s:** $2, 4, 6, 8, 10$
- $1 \times 2 = 2$
- $2 \times 2 = 4$
- $3 \times 2 = 6$
- $4 \times 2 = 8$
- $5 \times 2 = 10$

**Skip counting by 5s:** $5, 10, 15, 20, 25$
- $1 \times 5 = 5$
- $2 \times 5 = 10$
- $3 \times 5 = 15$

So when you skip count, you're already multiplying!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Brilliant work! In this lesson you learned:

- **Multiplication** means making **equal groups**
- $4 \times 3$ means **4 groups of 3**
- Multiplication is a shortcut for **repeated addition**
- **Arrays** show multiplication in rows and columns
- **Skip counting** is the same as multiplication

Look for equal groups around you -- eggs in cartons, wheels on cars, legs on animals!

workedExamples.title: Finding the Total from Equal Groups
workedExamples.problem: There are 5 nests and each nest has 3 eggs. How many eggs altogether?
workedExamples.explanation: Five groups of three is the same as adding 3 five times. $5 \times 3 = 15$.

workedExamples.title: Reading an Array
workedExamples.problem: An array has 3 rows with 4 counters in each row. How many counters?
workedExamples.explanation: An array of 3 rows and 4 columns has $3 \times 4 = 12$ items. You could also see it as 4 columns of 3, giving $4 \times 3 = 12$.
